question.text: The engineers had only begun analyzing the problem when a new discovery ___ their working model obsolete.

answer.explanation:
Render = Cause = Make
If the sentence uses past perfect tense before a "when" clause, we use past tense in the "when" clause.

(A) This is a comparative form using -er and “than”. Choice (B) is an incomplete equal comparison. Choice (C) is an incomplete superlative. Choice (D) incorrectly uses than with a superlative adjective.

question.text: The housekeeping staff comes on duty___2:00.

answer.explanation: (C) “At” is used widi specific hours of the day. Choice (A) means “inside”. Choice (B) is used with days of the week. Choice (D) means together.

question.text: We missed the deadline___our computer malfunctioned.

answer.explanation: (B) “Because” indicates a cause-and-effect relationship. Choices (A), (C), and (D) are not logical.
(C) “In” is used with cities. Choice (A) is used with days of the week. Choice (B) indicates a recipient. Choice (D) indicates a destination.
(B) This is an adjective used to modify the noun “market”. Choices (A) and (C) are nouns. Choice (D) is an adverb.

question.text: We will not send the payment___the invoice is corrected.

answer.explanation: (A) This indicates when the payment will be sent. Choices (B), (C), and (D) are not logical.

question.text: Most of the employees___in the company cafeteria.

answer.explanation: (C) Habitual action is expressed with the simple present tense. Choice (A) is a gerund. Choice (B) is base form. Choice (D) is an infinitive.

question.text: Salespeople___attract new clients receive a bonus.

answer.explanation: (D) The relative pronoun “who” refers to “salespeople” and acts as the subject of the clause. Choice (A) is possessive. Choice (B) is used to refer to things. Choice (C) is used as an object, not a subject.

question.text: The new instructions are___the old ones.

answer.explanation: (D) The comparative, using “more” and “than”, is used to compare the new instructions with the old ones. Choice (A) omits “than”. Choice (B) is an incomplete equal comparison. Choice (C) omits “more”.
